xxl.collections
Interface Queue

All Known Subinterfaces:
FIFOQueue, LIFOQueue
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractQueue, DecoratorQueue
public interface Queue
extends PeekIterator

The interface queue represents an user specified iteration over a collection of elements (also known as a sequence) with a peek method. This interface does not predefine any strategy for addition and removal of elements so that the user has full control concerning his strategy (e.g., FIFO (first in, first out), LIFO (last in, first out) etc.).

In contradiction to sets, queues typically allow duplicate elements. More formally, queues typically allow pairs of elements e1 and e2 such that e1.equals(e2), and they typically allow multiple null elements if they allow null elements at all.

See Also:
Function, Iterator, NoSuchElementException, PeekIterator

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a default queue. Each implementation of queue should have a function FACTORY_METHOD that implements three variants of invoke
  • Object invoke():
    • returns new Queue().
  • Object invoke(Object iterator):
    • returns new Queue(iterator).
  • Object invoke(Object[] internalDataStructure):
    • returns new Queue((<InternalDataStructure>)internalDataStructure[0]).
This field is set to ArrayQueue.FACTORY_METHOD.
See Also:
Function.invoke(), Function.invoke(Object), Function.invoke(Object[])
Method Detail

insert

public void insert(Object object)
Appends the specified element to the end of this queue. The end of the queue is given by its strategy.
Parameters:
object - element to be appended to the end of this queue.

insertAll

public void insertAll(Iterator objects)
Appends all of the elements in the specified iterator to the end of this queue. A possible implementation iterates over the specified iterator, inserting the elements obtained from it into this queue using the following code 
 while(objects.hasNext()) {
     insert(objects.next());
 }
Note, that this method is implemented in AbstractQueue. The end of the queue is given by its strategy. The behavior of this operation is unspecified if the specified iterator is modified while the operation is in progress.
Parameters:
objects - iterator whose elements are to be appended to the end of this queue.

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the queue has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
Specified by:
hasNext in interface PeekIterator
Returns:
true if the queue has more elements.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Returns the next element in the queue without removing it. The next element of the queue is given by its strategy.
Specified by:
peek in interface PeekIterator
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - queue has no more elements.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by this queue.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the queue. The next element of the queue is given by its strategy.
Specified by:
next in interface PeekIterator
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - queue has no more elements.

remove

public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying collection the last element returned by the queue (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek. Because of thinkable interactions with other methods (e.g., the hasNext method of a Filter with an underlying iterator removes elements from the iterator) the correct working of a queue can only be guaranteed when remove is immediately called after calls to next or peek. The behavior of a queue is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the queue is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
Specified by:
remove in interface PeekIterator
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next method.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by this queue.

replace

public Object replace(Object object)
               throws NoSuchElementException
Appends the specified element to the end of this queue and returns the next element in the queue. The end and the next element of the queue are given by its strategy.
Note that using a LIFO strategy forces to store the result of next() before inserting the specified element in order to return the replaced element.
Parameters:
object - element to be appended to the end of this queue.
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - queue has no more elements.

replaceAll

public Iterator replaceAll(Iterator objects)
                    throws NoSuchElementException
Appends all of the elements in the specified iterator to the end of this queue and returns an iterator having the same length iterating over the replaced (next) elements of the queue. The end and the next element of the queue are given by its strategy.
All implementations of this method should follow the principle of lazy evaluation i.e. the replacement of an element takes place when calling next() on the returned iterator. A possible implementation returns an iterator wrapping calls to replace(objects.next()).
Note that using a LIFO strategy forces to store the result of next() before inserting the specified element in order to return the replaced element.
Parameters:
objects - iterator whose elements are to be appended to the end of this queue.
Returns:
an iterator having the same length as objects and iterating over the replaced (next) elements of this queue.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - queue has no more elements.

size

public int size()
Returns the number of elements in this queue. If this queue contains more than Integer.MAX_VALUE elements, returns Integer.MAX_VALUE.
Returns:
the number of elements in this queue.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek operation is supported by this queue. (In other words, returns true if peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface PeekIterator
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by this queue.

clear

public void clear()
Removes all of the elements from this queue. The queue will be empty after this call returns so that size() == 0.
Note that the elements will only be removed from the queue but not from the underlying collection.

close

public void close()
Closes this queue and releases any system resources associated with it. This operation is idempotent, i.e., multiple calls of this method takes the same effect as a single call.
Note: This method is very important for queues using external resources like files or JDBC resources.
